Baltimore, January ;5.--By the schooner Belle
at This port last evening from La Guayra, we learn
that General Bolirar was within TWO days Journey
OF Caracas. His arrival was looked for with intense
anxiety.


A supplement to the ST. Thomas Times Of De
cember Cd contains account Of an action fought
in Cumana on the lth of November, between the
militia OF that place (who had declared themselves
in favour Of the line OF policy adopted by General
Paez) and the troops under command of General
Bermudez. The latter was defeated and was oblg
ed 10 hy to Barcelona. american.

a midshipman OF the U. S. Ship Cyane. who

Speaking on the subject Of the invasion OF Portu-
gal, the N. Y. Commercial says" We cannot
iorbear repeat, by way ofa caution against the ev
er-wakeful spirit of speculation that in our opinion
there will be nothing more than the mmicry Of war,
for a very short season Unless backed by France,
Spain car.not make war; she cannot move Of her
self and we can perceiv. no substantial reason
for supposing that France has had any hand in the
movement of Spain against Portugal. Ne'erthe-
less. war may grow out of the existing difficulties
and Eng and may avail herself OF the occasion to
seize upon Cuba. Upon this point government
must not slumber. We repeat wha, we have said
on former occasion: The United States must not
alow Cuba to pass into the hands Of any other for
eign po,cer. If the island is to change masters,
those masters must be ourselves"

.Maryland.-In the Senate of this State, Daniel
Sprigg having declined TO AXE the seat Senator,
10 which he had been chosen, Thomas Kennedy wa,
unanimously. and with universal appreciation, cho

From Virginia, we learn, that, on Saturday las,
John Tyter was elected Senator of the Unned
States, for six years from the third day Of March
next, 10 succeed Mr.. Randolph whose term OF
service will then expire. The vote in joint ballot
OF The two branches of the Legislature stood as
follows For John Tyler, lis; for John Randolph.
10; scattering, votes. A wide latitude is said
to have been taken in the debate the nominations
and much heat to have been exhibited both sides


n at. Intel.

The first moie:y. being six hundred and two


thousand font hundred and eighty dollars, OF the
SUN which Great Britain agreed to pay certain CT


izens Of the United States. for slaves carried off
during the last war, was paid by Mr. Vaughan, the
British Minister at the Department Of State. on


The 18th inst. The remainder is to be paid on the
first of August next. The payment was made by
the transfer of check for the above sum- drawn
by the Bank of the United States on its Office Of
Discount and Depose in Washington City, in ia
vor oil Mr.. Vaughan.


The Jackson papers in Philadelphia have publish
ed a letter, said to be from gentleman lin Della
vsre, which says that " in State are the people
lrs, friendly to the Administration than in this" ="
We presume this letter was manufactured for
party purpose-for no gentleman, unless a rery
ignorant one, would make such an assertion The
people OF this State have never manifested an un-
friendly disposition towards the present Admins


ralion--ad many of these Of them who preferred
other candidates to MIR. Adams, satisfied with


the measures he has pursued, and are too patriotic


10 join in The hue and cry against him, raised by
few disappointed ambitious parisans. The cleo


on of Messrs. Ridgely and M'Lane, both violcn'
right or wrong" opp.sers of the Administration


10 the Sena'e, has been brought forward ss addition
al evidence 10 support Of the decla alton contained
in the genllemans" letter. This is intended TO
produce an eiiec, abroad for here it we'll known
that the choice Of Senator'S did not turn upon the
question Of the next presidential election but was
solely contest between the democrats and federal.
ISIS, and it entirely owing to the latter having
ma orty in the Legislature, that Mcssrs. RIdgely
and Nj Lane were elected.

mandant OF the Arsenal, by blow which nearly
telled him to the ground he instantly returned The
compliment, and laid his assaiiant at his feet Du-
ring this afffay the press gang arrived with mus.
kels, bayonets, sc. attacked the MIdshipman and
beat him severely. Lieut.. Levy. first the Cyane,
who came to the scene of conflict, was also wound
cd ~ the bayone,s of the press gang. Capt. Huch-
e"s' Mate and men were pressed by the gang ;
and the Captain of Brig belonging 10 New York,
was taken by these marauders, and carried beyond
The suburbs OF the town, all oil them however, were
subsequently released. Beacon

Speaking on the subject Of the invasion OF Portu-
gal, the N. Y. Commercial says" We cannot
iorbear repeat, by way ofa caution against the ev
er-wakeful spirit of speculation that in our opinion
there will be nothing more than the mmicry Of war,
for a very short season Unless backed by France,
Spain car.not make war; she cannot move Of her
self and we can perceiv. no substantial reason
for supposing that France has had any hand in the
movement of Spain against Portugal. Ne'erthe-
less. war may grow out of the existing difficulties
and Eng and may avail herself OF the occasion to
seize upon Cuba. Upon this point government
must not slumber. We repeat wha, we have said
on former occasion: The United States must not
alow Cuba to pass into the hands Of any other for
eign po,cer. If the island is to change masters,
those masters must be ourselves"

States, for six years from the third day Of March
next, 10 succeed Mr.. Randolph whose term OF
service will then expire. The vote in joint ballot
OF The two branches of the Legislature stood as

thousand font hundred and eighty dollars, OF the
SUN which Great Britain agreed to pay certain CT


izens Of the United States. for slaves carried off

The 18th inst. The remainder is to be paid on the

The Jackson papers in Philadelphia have publish
ed a letter, said to be from gentleman lin Della
vsre, which says that " in State are the people
lrs, friendly to the Administration than in this" ="
We presume this letter was manufactured for
party purpose-for no gentleman, unless a rery
ignorant one, would make such an assertion The
people OF this State have never manifested an un-
friendly disposition towards the present Admins


ralion--ad many of these Of them who preferred
other candidates to MIR. Adams, satisfied with


the measures he has pursued, and are too patriotic


10 join in The hue and cry against him, raised by
few disappointed ambitious parisans. The cleo


on of Messrs. Ridgely and M'Lane, both violcn'
right or wrong" opp.sers of the Administration


10 the Sena'e, has been brought forward ss addition
al evidence 10 support Of the decla alton contained
in the genllemans" letter. This is intended TO
produce an eiiec, abroad for here it we'll known
that the choice Of Senator'S did not turn upon the
question Of the next presidential election but was
solely contest between the democrats and federal.
ISIS, and it entirely owing to the latter having
ma orty in the Legislature, that Mcssrs. RIdgely
and Nj Lane were elected.
